page.title: 15SHIPWRECKS NEAR BUDE
page.content: During the 19th century there were several ship-wrecks along this coast.A lot of ship-wrecks occurred near {Northcott Mouth.}They included the Surprise whose cargo was Clovelly Skiff, sloop which was importing oats, Ann'of St.Ives' which carried copper ore.In all the ships the crew were drowned.The remains of the Crystal Spring where auctioned in 1850.The hull, spars and masts where bought by the Petherick brothers for 10 guineas and the rest of the boat was sold for 9 shillings. Today the remains of a hull and boiler of a wreck can be seen on the north side of{Northcott Mouth.}At times the sea almost buries it in sand, though sometimes the wreck is more visible as the sea scours away the beach.Some remains have been taken to a museum in {Bude}near the canal lock-gates.
